title: in search of free alternative to font
content: basically looking for a free alternative to schoolbook.
author: Willo

comments.content:
Why does it have to be free?  
Why does it have to (Century, I assume?) Schoolbook?

FYI: Three weights of Century Old Style are bundled with Adobe CS2.  
Latin Modern Roman from [CTAN](http://web.archive.org/web/20131007014716/http:/www.ctan.org/tex-archive/fonts/lm/)  
 is not the most beautiful font in the world. But it is free and is in the same stylistic genre as Century.

F

Yeah, why does it have to be free?

What about Mark Simonson's [Grad](http://web.archive.org/web/20131007014716/http:/www.ms-studio.com/FontSales/grad.html), which is an updated version of Phil Martin's revision of Century Schoolbook?

You can get Grad Regular, Italic, and Bold for $29 each or all three for $59 at

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/grad/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131007014716/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/grad/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/grad/")

Rahim

Why has it to be free? Take a look at Ch. M.’s avatar: he rides a bike, can’t afford to buy a car, let be a font.

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO

See Typophile's ["Good Libre Fonts"](http://web.archive.org/web/20131007014716/http:/typophile.com/node/18207) page. Century Schoolbook L is one of the freely available URW fonts.

st

P.S. I see that the information on the wiki page doesn't include a great way to get these fonts, except by finding a friend with Linux. You could let me know if you are interested and don't have Linux experience.
